questions.question_text: Which of the following provides the MOST protection against zero day attacks via email attachments?

discussion.content:
Anti-spam refers to the use of any software, hardware or process to block spam from entering a system. The anti-spam software uses a set of protocols to determine unsolicited and unwanted messages and prevent those messages from getting to a user's inbox.

An antivirus is software that protects against computer viruses, a type of malware that self-replicates by inserting its code into other software programs. The best antivirus programs scan files to protect your computer and devices from such threats, while keeping resource consumption to a minimum.

questions.question_text: Which of the following allows a technician to gather information about the operating system?
Which of the following can be issued from the command line to find the layer 3 hops to a remote destination?

discussion.content:
I Guess 'Netstat A' is a typo or (more likely) a format display error on the web server in question - 'A' denoting the answer (traceroute - which by the way is correct), whilst the 'Correct Answer' section has what is seemingly the default wording ('Explanation') intended for the 'Discussion' field prompted with a button-style link denoted with the same name.

It's as if the text have somehow been shifted up from their normally allocated displays.

Just a mention as I have seen this occurrence numerous times throughout the Q&As...

You can break this question down by answer:
A. Wrong IP address - This would cause packet routing problems, but would not cause an interface to bounce.
B. Loopback not set - Would not effect link status, this is primarily used in BGP routing and has nothing to do with link state.
C. Bad wire - Since network wires don't move, this would typically cause an interface's line protocol to go and stay down.
D. Incorrect encapsulation - This would impact routing, not physical link state.
E. Duplex mismatch - By process of elimination, this is the only remaining answer. A mismatch in duplex between both sides of the connection will cause the link to bounce repeatedly.

Another way to look at it is based on the question. The thing to note is that it is asking about a physical layer issue (Interface flapping), and only C and E are physical layer problems. We know it can't be C since it is extremely unlikely a bad wire will "sometimes work". That leaves E as our only choice.

questions.question_text:
An administrator's network has OSPF for the internal routing protocol and has two interfaces that continue to flap. The administrator reviews the following output:
Fast ethernet 0 is up, line protocol is up
Int ip address is 10.20.130.5/25
MTU 1500 bytes, BW10000 kbit, DLY 100 usec
Reliability 255/255, Tx load 1/255, Rx load 1/255
Encapsulation ospf, loopback not set

Keep alive 10 -
Full duplex, 100Mb/s, 100Base Tx/Fx

Received 1052993 broadcasts -
1258 input errors
983881 packet output, 768588 bytes
1747 output errors, 0 collisions, 423 resets
Which of the following problems would cause the interface flap?

A contractor was hired to troubleshoot congestion issues on the network. After a few of the switches have been reconfigured/upgraded by the contractor, congestion worsens and collisions increase.
Which of the following is the BEST action to alleviate the situation?

discussion.content:
Answer D is correct, but the term 'upgrade' in the Question section may be also indicative of hardware, which, if this was the case, then a 'Downgrade of firmware' explained in Answer D would be nonsensical...

Case in point:

'An upgrade is the act of replacing your product with a newer, and often more superior, version or similar product. Therefore, an UPDATE modifies your current product while an UPGRADE totally replaces it. ... On the other hand, upgrades are distinct and do not need the older software to function'

What is the difference between upgrade and update?
https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-difference-between-upgrade-and-update

In a nutshell: the wording of the question are dubious at best and should be rephrased as students should not have to 

a) second guess
b) should be learning the RIGHT terminology esp. if English is not their native tongue 

Clarity in wording for a network engineer to comprehend is critical.

choices.D: Downgrade firmware and restore backup configuration
choices.B: Check the cabling on all switches for improper crossover use
choices.A: Allow the contractor to reset switches to factory defaults
choices.C: Document the changes that were made
